inputs:
Please answer the following questions about the structure of logical arguments.

Question: While abroad, John ate a food that he had never tried before.  The following day, he got sick.  While talking to his friend back home, John mentioned that this exotic food made him sick.  What is John failing to realize?
  option: His sickness was probably caused by a virus he got before dinner.
  option: There are likely other factors which could have made John sick.
  option: New food very rarely makes people sick.
  option: He is likely sick because of failing to exercise.
  option: There are benefits to being sick in a foreign country.
Answer:
targets: There are likely other factors which could have made John sick.
multiple_choice_targets: There are likely other factors which could have made John sick.
New food very rarely makes people sick.
His sickness was probably caused by a virus he got before dinner.
He is likely sick because of failing to exercise.
There are benefits to being sick in a foreign country.

inputs:
Please answer the following questions about the structure of logical arguments.

Question: A popular diet drink from a few years ago claimed to be able to replace all one’s daily food intake, by using a combination of supplements and natural ingredients to include the entire suite of nutrients recommended by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA).  The argument that this on its own suffices as a complete meal replacement rests on which of the following premises?
  option: The FDA does not know the full set of nutrients required by humans.
  option: The replacement drink is affordable by average families.
  option: The environmental impacts of producing the diet drink are negligible.
  option: Eating meat is harmful for health.
  option: The nutrients recommended by the FDA are sufficient for human health.
Answer:
targets: The nutrients recommended by the FDA are sufficient for human health.
multiple_choice_targets: The nutrients recommended by the FDA are sufficient for human health.
The replacement drink is affordable by average families.
Eating meat is harmful for health.
The environmental impacts of producing the diet drink are negligible.
The FDA does not know the full set of nutrients required by humans.

inputs:
Please answer the following questions about the structure of logical arguments.

Question: Skeptical of the hype surrounding self-driving car technology, Mark takes a bet with his friend that self-driving cars will not be driving on most US roads until well past the year 2030.  Part of Mark’s conviction is based on his expertise in LIDAR technology, which forms an integral part of the computer-vision systems in most self-driving cars.  Immediately after taking the bet, Mark attends a conference displaying the latest research in LIDAR technology, after which Mark tells his friend that he regrets taking the bet.  Which of the following is a reasonable inference?
  option: Mark invested in a self-driving car company at the LIDAR conference.
  option: Mark still believes that self-driving cars will not work in this century.
  option: Mark learned something at the conference suggesting that LIDAR technology would not work.
  option: Mark did not change his beliefs on the feasibility of self-driving technology at the conference.
  option: Mark learned something at the conference that gave him more confidence in LIDAR technology.
Answer:
targets: Mark learned something at the conference that gave him more confidence in LIDAR technology.
multiple_choice_targets: Mark learned something at the conference that gave him more confidence in LIDAR technology.
Mark learned something at the conference suggesting that LIDAR technology would not work.
Mark still believes that self-driving cars will not work in this century.
Mark did not change his beliefs on the feasibility of self-driving technology at the conference.
Mark invested in a self-driving car company at the LIDAR conference.

inputs:
Please answer the following questions about the structure of logical arguments.

Question: By looking at which direction shadows of objects point on the ground, one can generally determine whether one is in the northern or southern hemisphere.  For example, if the shadow of a lamp post points more south than north, one can infer that the sun is in the northern portion of the sky and thus one is in the southern hemisphere.  This inference relies on which assumption?
  option: If the sun is in the Eastern portion of the sky, it is before noon.
  option: The sun only casts shadows in the southern hemisphere.
  option: If the sun is in the Northern portion of the sky, one is in the southern hemisphere.
  option: If one is in the southern hemisphere, the sun will appear in the Northern portion of the sky.
  option: If the sun is in the Western portion of the sky, it is after noon.
Answer:
targets: If the sun is in the Northern portion of the sky, one is in the southern hemisphere.
multiple_choice_targets: If the sun is in the Northern portion of the sky, one is in the southern hemisphere.
If the sun is in the Eastern portion of the sky, it is before noon.
If the sun is in the Western portion of the sky, it is after noon.
If one is in the southern hemisphere, the sun will appear in the Northern portion of the sky.
The sun only casts shadows in the southern hemisphere.

inputs:
Please answer the following questions about the structure of logical arguments.

Question: Recent evidence suggests that long periods of sitting can be harmful for one’s health.  This is partly based on a study which found that long periods of sitting are associated with higher levels of obesity and cardiovascular disease.  This argument rests on which of the following assumptions?
  option: Obesity and cardiovascular disease are not caused by smoking.
  option: Rates of sitting have risen dramatically in recent years.
  option: Obesity and cardiovascular disease do not cause long periods of sitting.
  option: A causal link exists between sitting and obesity.
  option: Obesity rates have been rising over the past several years.
Answer:
targets: Obesity and cardiovascular disease do not cause long periods of sitting.
multiple_choice_targets: Obesity and cardiovascular disease do not cause long periods of sitting.
Obesity rates have been rising over the past several years.
Rates of sitting have risen dramatically in recent years.
A causal link exists between sitting and obesity.
Obesity and cardiovascular disease are not caused by smoking.

Please answer the following questions about the structure of logical arguments.

Question: Advocates of teaching children to play an instrument suggest that it improves mathematical ability later in life.  To justify this belief, they point to observational studies showing that on average, children who were forced to learn an instrument by their parents do better on tests of mathematical reasoning ability as adults.  Which of the following facts, if true, would render their argument void?
  option: Children who are forced to learn an instrument get into college more often than their peers.
  option: Not all instruments improve mathematical ability.
  option: Learning math improves musical ability.
  option: Children who are forced to learn an instrument are also given more mathematical training.
  option: Musical ability does not correlate with mathematical ability in early childhood.
Answer:
targets: Children who are forced to learn an instrument are also given more mathematical training.
multiple_choice_targets: Children who are forced to learn an instrument are also given more mathematical training.
Not all instruments improve mathematical ability.
Learning math improves musical ability.
Children who are forced to learn an instrument get into college more often than their peers.
Musical ability does not correlate with mathematical ability in early childhood.

Question: In an effort to keep their citizens safe from car accidents, city council members mandated that every town resident wear a seatbelt while in a moving vehicle, and everyone complied immediately.  A month later, a dissenting councilman noted that everyone who had been injured or killed in a car accident in the past week had been wearing a seatbelt; therefore, he concluded, seatbelts were ineffective in preventing injuries in car accidents.  Which of the following is an explanation of why the councilman’s argument is incorrect?
  option: Everyone who didn’t wear a seatbelt has been arrested.
  option: The town’s seatbelt mandate had yet to go into effect.
  option: Not all cars were equipped with seatbelts.
  option: All people, both injured and not, are wearing seatbelts.
  option: People who don’t wear seatbelts don’t report their accidents.
Answer:
targets: All people, both injured and not, are wearing seatbelts.
multiple_choice_targets: All people, both injured and not, are wearing seatbelts.
People who don’t wear seatbelts don’t report their accidents.
Everyone who didn’t wear a seatbelt has been arrested.
The town’s seatbelt mandate had yet to go into effect.
Not all cars were equipped with seatbelts.

Question: A cop, investigating a murder, learned from an eyewitness that the murderer was seen running from the crime scene wearing a bright blue hat.  Later in the day, the cop saw Mr. Ali walking down the street wearing a bright blue hat and immediately arrested him for the crime.  Which of the following facts, if true, would make the cop’s reasoning legitimate?
  option: Everyone in the town owns a bright blue hat.
  option: No one besides Mr. Ali owns a bright blue hat.
  option: Mr. Ali was friends with the murder victim.
  option: Every man in the town owns a bright blue hat.
  option: Mr. Ali was known to be on the other side of town when the murder occurred.
Answer:
targets: No one besides Mr. Ali owns a bright blue hat.
multiple_choice_targets: No one besides Mr. Ali owns a bright blue hat.
Everyone in the town owns a bright blue hat.
Every man in the town owns a bright blue hat.
Mr. Ali was known to be on the other side of town when the murder occurred.
Mr. Ali was friends with the murder victim.

Please answer the following questions about the structure of logical arguments.

Question: In an argument about the morality of eating animal products, one of the people involved argued that eating animal products is legal in the United States, and therefore is not an immoral action.  Their opponent pointed out that in the 1700s, someone in the United States could have used the exact same argument to justify owning slaves.  This counterargument relies on which assumption?
  option: Eating animal products was illegal in the 1700s.
  option: In the 1800s, owning slaves was legal in the United States.
  option: Eating animal products will always be legal in the United States.
  option: Eating animal products is allowed for the same reason slavery was allowed.
  option: In the 1700s, owning slaves was legal in the United States.
Answer:
targets: In the 1700s, owning slaves was legal in the United States.
multiple_choice_targets: In the 1700s, owning slaves was legal in the United States.
In the 1800s, owning slaves was legal in the United States.
Eating animal products is allowed for the same reason slavery was allowed.
Eating animal products was illegal in the 1700s.
Eating animal products will always be legal in the United States.

Question: One day in school, the maths teacher was absent.  The substitute teacher asked the kids what they had been learning; they said that they were learning trigonometry.  The substitute told them that instead of teaching them useless facts about triangles, he would instead teach them how to work with probabilities.  What is the substitute teacher implying with this statement?
  option: He believes that probability theory is a useless subject.
  option: He thinks understanding probabilities is more useful than trigonometry.
  option: He is very concerned about following the school’s curriculum.
  option: He believes that mathematics does not need to be useful to be interesting.
  option: He thinks that probability theory involves studying triangles.
Answer:
targets: He thinks understanding probabilities is more useful than trigonometry.
multiple_choice_targets: He thinks understanding probabilities is more useful than trigonometry.
He believes that probability theory is a useless subject.
He believes that mathematics does not need to be useful to be interesting.
He thinks that probability theory involves studying triangles.
He is very concerned about following the school’s curriculum.

Question: Cryptocurrencies are sometimes derided as potential units of exchange because they have no intrinsic value.  People who make this argument are implying which of the following?
  option: It is important for a currency to have intrinsic value.
  option: Only the US Dollar, but not gold, has intrinsic value.
  option: Only gold, but not the US Dollar, has intrinsic value.
  option: Bitcoins are not physical objects.
  option: Only physical objects have intrinsic value.
Answer:
targets: It is important for a currency to have intrinsic value.
multiple_choice_targets: It is important for a currency to have intrinsic value.
Only physical objects have intrinsic value.
Only gold, but not the US Dollar, has intrinsic value.
Bitcoins are not physical objects.
Only the US Dollar, but not gold, has intrinsic value.
